texts.shortText:
Very diverse genus of relatively large, off-white isopods characterized by having five free abdominal segments and a distinct ‘’tail-fan’ formed of a rounded to triangular pleotelson (ornamented with a variety of knobs, pustules, ridges or setae that distinguish the various species) and a sturdy pair of uropods with more-or-less equal length branches.

This species has finely crimped posterior margins to each thoracic segment. These become larger in each segment, becoming distinct teeth along each of the free abdominal segments. The pleotelson is long and pointed and had a pair of dorsal longitudinal ridges along it centre and fine crimp marking along its edges. The uropods have unusually broad and scoop-like outer branches.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Lüderitz in Namibia to East London.
Poorly known, but one of several species of this genus common on rocky shores and on shallow subtidal reefs, all of which are thought to be scavengers.
Presumed to be either a predator and/or to scavenge on dead animal matter.
Like all isopods the eggs are released into a marsupium between the walking legs of the female, where they are fertilized by the male and develop into fully-formed juveniles before being released.

A very diverse genus including many common and easily confused species, including over 20 reported from South Africa. The combination of crimped or toothed posterior margin of the last thoracic and all abdominal segments and pair of longitudinal ridges along pointed pleotelson are unique to this species though.

Barnard, KH (1914). Contributions to the crustacean fauna of South Africa: additions to the marine Isopoda, with notes on some previously incompletely known species. Annals of the South African Museum 10: 325–442.

Kensley, B (1978). Guide to the Marine Isopods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town. 173 pp. (p. 71).
